div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,614] ALEXANDRIA, MONDAY, NOVEMBER 19, 1906. . ;[SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.
Throw Steel Nibs Away!
They waste time, are costly to use, wear out, scratch, etc.
Try a "Swan" Fountain Pen.
Prices from 10/6
Sold by all Stationers and Importers in Cairo and Alexandria.
Catalogue free.
Mable, Todd & Bard, High Holborn, London.

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p:
Mail and Passenger Steamships. Regular three-weekly Service from HAMBURG,
via ANTWERP & MALTA, to ALEXANDRIA and vice-versa, admitting goods from
all chief German Railway Stations on direct Bill of Landing to ALEXANDRIA
and all chief ports of Egypt, Syria, etc., at favourable through rates of
DEUTSCHE VERKEHR (traffic).
EXPECTED AT ALEXANDRIA.

November 21 from Antwerp.

S.S. Kypros
November 21 from Hamburg bound
for Beyrout.

S.S. Lemnos
November 23 from Hamburg bound
for Beyrout.
For tariff and particulars apply to ADOLPHE STROSS, Alexandria, Agent.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p:
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA,
MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe
for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every
Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for
Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to
LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN,
MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and
SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.

N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table
wine free.

Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at
Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other
Tourist Agency.

div.head: SUDAN GOVERNMENT RAILWAYS.
div.p: CAIRO-KHARTOUM SUMMER MAIL SERVICE.--SUMMER TIME-TABLE 1906.
Commencing from 1st of April, 1906, until further notice

‡Sleeping and Dining Cars. — During the month of April Sleeping and Dining Care
trains leave Cairo for Luxor on Wednesdays, Mondays and Saturdays at 6.30 p.m.
and Luxor for Cairo on Sundays, Tuesdays and Thursdays at 6.30 p.m.

From 1st of May 1908, these trains will be suppressed, but Dining and Sleeping
Care will be attached to the ordinary night Tains from Cairo and Luxor three
times a week, on the same above mentioned days. 14-6-907

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4
p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan,
Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival
Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe
Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi & Trieste Line.

Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 10 and 24 October, 7 and 21 November, 5
and 19 December.
Syrian-Cyprus-Caramanian Line.

Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 8 and 22 October, 5 and 19 November, 3,
17 and 31 December.
Syrian-Caramanian Line.

Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 1, 15 and 29 October, 12 and 26
November, 10 and 24 December.
Far East Lines.

October, 3 November.

October, 8 Nov., 8 Dec.

4 p.m.

To Suez, Aden, Karachi and Bombay about 13
Nov., 1 Dec (Winter Line).
East African Line.

Delagoa-Bay, and Durban about 3
Oct., 2 Nov., 3 Dec..

div.head: EASTERN EXCHANGE HOTEL, PORT SAID.
div.p: First Class Hotel. Modern in all respects.

Fire-proof, Drained to the Sea, Lifts, Electric Light, English and French
Billiards, Fresh and Salt Water Baths.
The Coolest Summer Residence in Egypt.

Special terms to Cairo Residents and their families desirous of enjoying the cool
air and sea bathing during the summer months.
Dragomans in Hotel Uniform Meet all Trains and Steamers.

div.head: Tewfik Palace Hotel.
div.p: Helouan, near Cairo.

Formerly the favourite Residence of H.H. the Khedive. Perfect Sanitation.–Purest
Desert air. Electric Light. Hot and old baths attached to most rooms. House
warmed by special system of Radiators, adjoining the Golf Links and Race Course,
Tennis, Billiards, Garden and open air palm house, good stabling , dark room.
Excellent Table. Moderate Charges.

div.head: Calvert's Carbolic Toilet Soap
div.p: Ensures a Clear, Soft Skin.

It is pure throughout, fragrantly perfumed, emollient, and antisceptic, (10%
crystal carbolic). It quickly removes dust and dirt, takes away the unpleasant
effects of perspiration, and leaves instead a delicious feeling of thorough
purification.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p:
Yesterday opened with a light breeze from the N.N.E. but towards noon the
wind suddenly changed to the N.N.W. The day was rather warm, but becme
beautifully cool in the evening. Barometer steady.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p:
SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including
delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber’s address) P.T. 231½ per
annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries
in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½
(£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from
the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages,
or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T.
10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for
standing advertisements.

ADVERTISEMENTS and SUBSCRIPTIONS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques
to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.

Street, E.C.

THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905.
THE RAID THAT TAftRI).
The no«rs of the oeptqre of

Sivo importance thereto, qenerai Botha gnJ his follow-leaden are politicians sa well at soldiers, and they will not let slip a chance of demanding a recompense for their loysltv. The grant of a constitution will not be enough . an extension of political privileges will - be demanded by the men who years ago were fighting ua tooth and ^i|, and we doubt whether the Liberal Government will be ready to resist such demands unleu and until the Opposition shows by its energetic criticism of any conceuiona that the country is not prepared I-' jllow the Transvaal something like qutbponij «o soon after tbequondara-rulon of that State attempted the conquest of South Africa. While tho Transvaal and tho Orange River Colony will no doubt become in a few years' tlma «> self-governing as Natal or Cape Colony are now, there is no object in unduly hastcnii.; the proceM without assuring ourselves that the grant of still wider self-government is both safe and politic. We have good reason to thank tho Bocre of tho Transvaal for the correctness of their attitude during Ferreira. abortive raid, but we need not on that oreoun: repeal the Arms Ordinances or replace the preacot High Commissioner by President
Steyn or Ocnornl Do lq Hoy.

div.head: PLAGUE IN BARRACKS. ENGLISH EX-SOLDIER SUCCUMBS.
div.p: A death from plague Em occnrred at Masta-pba I’a<h» barracks, Alexandria, whore the 2nd Battalion Royal Dublin Fusiliers aro at*-
- tioned.

The victim's name is Wilky, a man of 32 yoars, who was formerly a private in the 2nd Battalion Royal Berkshire!, and bad been for the last three years employed as assistant io the grocery bar at Mustapha canteen.

The doceased had only been ill for threo days, first showing suspicions symptoms on Wednesday last and expiring on Satarday in hospital, shortly after being admitted. His foneral took plaoe yesterday morning, the deceased being accorded tbo nsnal military honoors. Three hundred men of the Dublin Fosiliers and representatives of tho Departmental Corps accompanied the body to its last resting place at tbo British oemetery, where tbo bnrial service was to id by the Roy. A. Longley.

The qoarters occupied by tbo deceased have been thoroughly disinfeo»od, and every precaution has been tiken by the military author ities to prevent an extension of the disease. A tent has been erected on a waste piece of land near the sea where the other men employed in the grocery bar have been iso'a'ed and aro medically examined lonr times a day.

Io anticipation of tho deputore of the Khedive for Cairo on the 24th inst, the Khedvial Maieh are to day despatching their farnitnre and other belongings by a special goods train to the capital.
Alexandria Book Club

The Book Glob at Alexandria has recently received a large nomher oL additions to i's catalogue, mmberipg from 2,121 to 2,213. and including many recent publications. A list of the new books has been issued.-

Yesterday afterutwo "the coast guards confiscated, on the quay, .(dor parcels of hashish which tiro seamen, yl Russian and a Taik, were attempting to smuggle through the Customs. " ‘

Toe$ilve«tre French cimody company will n ake their first appearanoe at the Alhambra Theatre this evening in "La Grando Marmcre," a play in fiee acts by Georges Ohne’, anthor of "L* Maltre des Forges."

A few days ago ao Egyptian statfette was stolen from the toovre a* Paris. No clue as to .the identity of the robbers has been discovered'' A fresh robbery was committed on Tbnrsday week. The thieves got away with a statoette of tho second oentury »c., known pa the Spanish Statoette, which was exhibited it Salon Dieo La Foy.

and M. Runkewilz announce that their naau R:vage Hitel at Rumleh will be oloaed dorii g tbo winter month. Their well-kwwn Savoy Hotel at Luxor will open on Deoember 1. At thia splendidly sitoated hotel great improvements bare teen effected during the summer, to that vijitors to Luxor will find every'hing-required fit a pleasant stay, as also oonveoiet cos for enjoyable excursions. body.p: Ao anecdote which the l&te Mr. Lecky ased

to toll of Napoleon at 8t. Helena may he reotlled ^iays the "Weetminster G. zette”)’in connexion with the visit of the Channel Fleet to the Shannon. A Captain Watson, in command of a British »h>p of war which touchod at St. Hplena, visited Napoleon at Longwood. When the exEmperor beard that Captain Watson was a Limorick man, he displayed the most minote knowledge of the Shannon from its month to Limerick. Captain Watson was amazed at Napo'cun's knowledge derived from a cartful stndy if maps and.charts. the Emperor thereupon frtnklystati -.g that a descent open Ireland had long been among his pr-jeote, and flKat the oardinal mistake of his lifo was h-s preference of a campaign in Egypt loan V invasion nt Ireland.

div.head: HOTEL TRUST
div.p:
A MILLION OF CAPITAL
Mr. Biner, of the National Hotels apd Residences .Company, returned this morning to Cairo from Assonan,where he has been engaged connection wilh tho choice ft a site for a
hotel to be built by bis new hotel treat.
The treat will have a capital of a million
sterling, hold mainly by E'glith subscribers, part of which will be expended in tbe oonrtruo tion of large and up to date hutols at Alexandria. Cairo, and op river.
Tho issue will probably take plaoe in December.

div.head: STATE RAILWAYS
IMPORTANT INNOVATION
div.p:
Tbo Egyptian State Railways intend to commence some important work early next year in connection with the decentralisation of the railway organisation between Cairo and Aaaiont, which ia to be all transferred to Minieb, ■here the Locomotive Department, the Traflio Department, and the Engineering Department
will all be aitnated.
Minieb, too, ia to ho the head centre of the agticnltnral railway, whirh waa formerly the Sooreriei railway and waa taken over by the Quverpin'nt.

body.div:
LONDON TO PORT SUDAN The pioneer vessel of a row steamship line which has been- ettablisbod bo'ween London and Fort Sudan ^ill loave Alexandria for tbo latter port to-day, taking with her a foil cargo, half of which was shipped at Alexandria, Mosers. Barber & Son acting as agents, and the other half in London. The vessel, whioh, we understand, will be the first to sail from Alex-a for Fort Sudan direct, is tbo Dunkeld (4,600 tors), belonging to tbe London and East .African Line, who are establiehing a ithly service between London and Port Sadan, calling at Alexandria on the way.
The mastar of the Dunkeld, Captain Dob-eon, is n
long been oonneeted with the Papayanni Linr. horn

NOTES PROM 8UAKIN.
(From our Correspohdbst.)
Soakin. November 14. Among the passengers by the Khedivial Mail steamer Kosaeir from 8orz for Port Sndan, wore El Kaimaksm Dro/y Bey, R. N.. Controller Sudan Ports, and Mr. Guthe, agent for Mr. George Meinecke, oT Sots, who have ostabliihsd an agency for shipping and other butines*. The firm expect in a few days a steamer of the Hamburg-America'^Lino and another of tha Norddeutacher L'oyd, both from Suez with a general cargo for Port Sudan.
A few days ago the port polioo at Port Sudan, ocdor the command of Ycsbashi • Daaonki Efleodi, »e:zid a quantity of hashiah from the Khedivial ateamer Mahallab. The ! Rsis of the Mahallab, while bargaining for tho a lie of the drug, was surprised by Yuabaahi Dssouki, and the culprit was taken before the Civil Court, where he was eintenced to J-two years' imprisonment and tho hashish was ordered to be burnt
Mr. Gehohan, sub agent of the Bank of Egypt, Suakin, and Mr. W H. Biiley, Inspector , of Bridges, Sudan Government Railways, Suakin, were pasaeogers by the Koisoir from Suez and lauded here yesterday.
There have su far been very few applications for the lota of land which the Sudan Government is desirous of leasing for 80 yoars. and , it ia not likely that many more applicants wil1 ! oomn forward, as the price is considered i too high.

Marriage of Col. Davidson In Hive Pariah Ch-ircM* on Saturday week, Lient. Colonel C. J. Lloyd David«on, D.S.O., commanding the I«t Battalion Royal Inhiakill-iuR Fusilier'*, and late i ( >K& 1st Battalion at ( Cairo, on'y eorvivitjg son of vfie late Mr.'James J Brehnc-r DavId-ob. of Eglioton and Poyle Park, .00 Dorry,. Ireland, waa married to Nathalie, ' daughter of Culoiel A. B. Curnberlege, of Kingefield, Soatbwicx. Saaaex. The bride, ahi w*i given away by hor brother, Captain Cumkerlege, bad a gown made after the Gitins-through stylo in picture tattn,the bodioe having a yoke ot Cue old point de'Vohise, while a toile veil vni worn over a coronet of orapge bbssems. Five bridesmaids—Mist Florence E. Gnldie.iod M-aa Kathleen Jdaro (Morins of the bride). Mita Altera Donglaa, Miu Malcolm Sim, and Miaa May Spaikea—vfeie in attjhd-anoe, dressed, Romney'tyle, in white garrow 'y atriped si’k. TJie i ffieistinj clergymen were Canon T.' Peacey, the Rev. C..A'. Maili, and the Rev. T. Miller. Lieut Randall Ball, Rtyak Inniakilliug Pusfliers, ’»•«. be»t *<n- After the cerfmci.y a reception was held by MrC Comherlege. The bridegroom, the beat mar, and Captain Combprlege were in uniform.

STEAMER MOVEMENTS The Menage riot Maritime* 8.3 Ejnatenr, fn m M«'>eillcr, parsed the Straita of Meaaina on 8atorilny, and ia duo here to morrow w-rning.
The Mora liner 8.8. 8eti sailed Irora Malta on 8alorday afternoon, and is dna here to morrow af'ernOon with paaaeogera, mails,and general cargo.

Cairo In Winter
PROSPECTS OF THE SOICAL SEASON At in other years, the feast of Beyram strikes the first chorda of the opening chorea of the Cairo "Season j” and judging from the signs ot the times thia winter bids lair to be a greater aacooss than its predecessor. Indeed, Cairo baa already shaken the summer sleep Irom its eyes and on every aide preparations are being made to welcome back the expected guesti and to attraot the new ones. Nearly all the well known roaidonta have onoo more returned to their oomfortable quarters, and each day seer mure lamiliar faces io tho streets.
Changes thero are in plenty. New baildings have sprung up like mushrooms einoe the spring, and alterations surronnd one on evtry •ide. The new 8emiramis Hotel on the river bank baa already attained gigantio site, and though etill tar from being oomplete, it' promises to be habitable before the winter is half over. Tho extension of the Savoy is still in the bands of the builder, but much will be done in tho next few weeks, and the devoted patrons of this most favoured hotel need have no fear that their'oomfort will suffer in any way after its dours are onoe opened.
The improvements at Sbepheard't have already been enlarged upon in these oolumns.The additions reflect the greatest oredit on those who are responsible for them, and add fresh loitre to the historio house. The band which plays there on 8atnrdsy afternoons add, considerably to its popularity, and even tho* early io the season it is difficult to find an empty tea-table during the length of the programme. Modarn Qhaalrah.
Ubetireh is fast becoming an enormons suburb of handsome villas ; new roads are being oat in all directions, and even the gorgeous gardens of the Ubetireh Palaoe Hotel have been requisitioned by the ever spreading oom-moDity. There be many who lament the ruthless destruction of this beautiful lung of Cairo, bnt such valaable property oould hardly be exported to remain intact New regulations restriotieg the traffic through the grounds of the Sporliug Club have oome into force this week ; and in fatare we hover like houris shot oat from Paradise unless we bear oar magic badges oonspiououi on oor persons. These precautions have doubtless been proved necessary, and are conducive to all those who have a claim upon the clnb, but a certain portion of the community is none too well pleased at the restriction.
It is early days to dilate upon the social events of ths future, but everything points to there being a plethora of eutertainments before many weeks are over. Both Shepheard's and the Mena Home Hotels have started with very successful small dance,; and the visit of Mme Jane Hading to the Theatre Abbas this week ooght to prove a great attraction. The first Skye meeting is dated for the 30th, and alter that we may expert the osbal rash of engagements and festivities which make Cairo what it is—the finest winter playground in the world.

THE SULTAN'S HEIRS A Constantinople eohespond&nt. wha baa nxceptional'means of knowing writes to thq 'Manchester Guardian" j—
"Europe shoo'd know that, b}-their position in the taj d ostler dt srooession.etwo Ottonav^ prinops may he called^ on in^l^' nqt djjjanti fatare to direct the destiny of Turkpy. .
‘ Mohammed Re4>«d feffendi, thetairp}/ ■uranSve, Is y distinguished arid ifaod fcatted ' prince, Worthy ot all respect . *'
"The second neir is Ynnnf Iuodin f ffcndi, wboipaaonof Sultan Abdul .A ri and is 49 years old* He is thorough odmpefcnt to take up the tsslr of gakermpont^ he is very energetic and hap been educated and trained like Euro-| peso princes ; be is a oonvinood supporter of reforms and PSrliatnentarianirm. BIG LOCAL FLOTATION
TO PUSH MANCHESTER GOODS TO PUSH MANCHESTER GOODS.
A big flntation io shortly to be made io connection with the placing of Manchester goods nn thsBgyptian market, ciopled with a big banking ooncern. The oompsny is to be floated in Bgypt andin England, and the capital is to be over halfa-millioo.

EMPIRE GROWN COTTON
SUCCESS OF EGYPTIAN VARIETIES empire grown COTTON. SUCCESS OP EGYPTIAN VARIETIES.
The ooancil of the British Cotton-growing
Association, in their second annnal report, express themaelve* as strorgly of opinion that the time (or mere experiments has passed, and that tbo oase is proved. "All the ootton Lancashire require*,” they say, 'can be grown within the limits of the Empire.” The loss on the year’s working amounts to £19.414 6a. 9*., bat this is shown to be a relative improvement of £15,834 17s. 6d. on last year's result, and the ooancil hope to reduce the loss still farther 1907, and by 1903 to show an oven acoount or posaibly a profit. Meanwhile an argent appeal is made for more capital.
The accounts for the work in Lagos show a profit of £9.489 4 a. 5J., this being equal, after the payment of all expenses, including depto-oiation and a proportion of the home expenditure, to a net surplos of £305 10«. 9d. It is hoped that next year Northern Nigeria and the Gold Coast will also prove a son roe of inoome. The total oapital of the association at present is £217 273, and the whole of the proposed capital—£500,000—will be required I very shortly.
I The work aooompli«hed in the various Colonies is reviewed in the report Io the West Indies good progress hu been made, while West Alrioa as a whole has exceeded expectation*, some disappointment as regards Sierra Leone being more than compensated for by the results shown by the Gold Coast and Lagos.
“Hugo Poaalbllltlaa.
The results in Soatbsrn Nigeria have been
disappointing, and io Northern Nigeria, whioh is described as having "hngc possibilities aa the great ootton field of the futore,” the "main hopes of the association are oentred." In British Central Afriot the crop was to a great extent a lailnre. A beginning has been made British Bast Afr'ot, and the association ia al»b at work, either direotly or through other agencies, in Uganda, Rhodesia, South Africa, and E-ypt.
Dealing with the experiments in India arith Egyptian yarn, the report state,: It is now practically established that Egyptian oottoo be eoooMsfully grown in India, aud as fully 1,000,000 acres are available, provided irrigation works are carried ont, the Association can confidently look to Sind to supplement the Egyptian cotton orop.
The onltivation of long-stapled ootton in Ceylon is making great progres*. Shipments of Egyptian cotton have realised 9jd. per poond and Sea Island ootton has been sold at le. per ponnd.
In E*,t Africa also Egyptian seed has been □sod with good results.
I A repreieutative sent to British Bast Africa is stated to have reported most favoarably ol the prospects of an immediate and large extension of ootton cultivation there. The quality prodnood is of the Egyptian type, and is exceedingly good.
PAN ISLAMISM IN EGYPT.
The letter whioh we publish below wss received some time ago by "Al Mokattam," and is an interesting proof that:
1. Despite all the dementia of the Nationalist Press, Pan-blamism was preached, and vigorously preached, daring the past summer ;
2. That there are Egyptian Moslems who have the intelligence to comprehend the dangers of a propaganda ot di,integration and the eoarage to oppose it pnblio'y : —
To the Editors of "Al Mokattam."
Kindly publish the following nnder my •igna’nre.
There has been ranch talk lately about tbs charge ot fanaticism miadqageiiut ns by Sir B. Grey and abont Pan-Islamism.rTbe Egyptians know nothing of fanatiobm tbtey are known' for their character. The charge fallstm the news-docile papers t hataroshboting for Pan Islami'tn and whioh gave to this word a political meaning before Eorope This Pan Islamism ha* brought »n sorts of trouble upon as. Ws Egyptians have nothing to do with politics and we make no dfitinetion between Christians and Mobs-Sedan*.
jb papers that preach Pan-Islami*m.! Has there ever been a time when all Mohamedans ’ wire nnder nne government siooe the day, of Moawiya I We have gained nothing by ibis polioy of yours. If yon do not stop here, we •hall lose what authority we have now, and the Government will not listen to as ia fetare.
0 ye papers that preach Pan-Islamism ' Why preach patriotism I Yon ahonld try to make primary education general ; yon should innnd high schools where the young men will be taught patriotism and independence—not making any diatinetion between Christians and Mohamedans. Why do yon oot try to separate Egypt from Turkey and pay the tribute given to the lat'er for education T Doe, Tarkey spend Ibis tribute In defending as when it waa only yesterday that we were almost going to war with her for some land in Sinaj I Doeeshe spend the money in guarding the ronte of the
Ei’grims—you know how mnoh we aoff*r at the ands of ths Governors in Arabi*. If yon are patrio'io yon should preach patriotism Then we may hope to have a representative body, and detach Bgypt from Turkey.
AbdklMo'ti HuMBIV. Omda ofSamaleh, Peooas, Charkia,

ZIZINIA THEATRE
"LE MAITRE DE FORGES" George, Oboet'i "Msl're de Forge*" dors oot belong solely to the 19th end 29th centurio,; it is e pley for ell time We can picture some Cougreve or Utway treatiug the snbjeot nnder some snch style as "Pride for Pride"; Shakespeare might have resuscitated in its favour the old title of "Love’s labour Woo," while the theme it one roond which Boccaccio might well have woven one of his romanoe*. May be it is the very romance, adaptable to all afci, which makes the play to a oertain ex’ent ontrne to life. What thinking womir, sach aa Claire, would, by coopting her husband's deeds to bis word*, have for a moment doubted the continuity of bis love 1 Wbat intelligent man, ol Philippe's stamp, whoso love, thoogh selfdenying, mast have ever been on the lookout for a spark of sympathy, coaid have so long remained blind to the change in his wife's affections ; the more so, as Claire mikes no attempt to nae the liberty, granted her by hatband on bis lrnrning her love for the Dao de Blignj!
